Basic usage of the ‘psychinterpreter’ Package

Matthias Kloft

2025-11-02

Source: vignettes/articles/01-Basic_Usage.qmd

Overview

This document demonstrates the functionality of the psychinterpreter package using the Big Five personality data from the psych package. The Big Five Inventory (BFI) is a widely-used personality assessment that measures five major dimensions of personality: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.

We’ll test all major features of psychinterpreter including:

  • Basic factor analysis interpretation
  • Persistent chat sessions for efficient LLM usage
  • Export functionality across multiple formats
  • Advanced interpretation features

Setup and Data Preparation 

library(psychinterpreter)
library(ellmer)
library(psych)
library(dplyr)

Attaching package: 'dplyr'
The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag
The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(here)
here() starts at C:/Users/Matze/AppData/Local/Temp/Rtmp0IoNeb/pkgdown-quarto-a09025bd17c9
library(pander)

# Load the BFI dataset and dictionary
data("bfi")
data("bfi.dictionary")

Preparing the BFI Data

Exclude demographic variables for factor analysis

bfi <- bfi[,1:25]
bfi.dictionary <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ]
# Show the first few rows
head(bfi)
# Display the BFI dictionary showing item descriptions and keying
print(bfi.dictionary |> select(Item))
                                        Item
A1 Am indifferent to the feelings of others.
A2         Inquire about others' well-being.
A3               Know how to comfort others.
A4                            Love children.
A5                 Make people feel at ease.
C1                   Am exacting in my work.
C2     Continue until everything is perfect.
C3            Do things according to a plan.
C4           Do things in a half-way manner.
C5                            Waste my time.
E1                         Don't talk a lot.
E2     Find it difficult to approach others.
E3             Know how to captivate people.
E4                      Make friends easily.
E5                              Take charge.
N1                         Get angry easily.
N2                     Get irritated easily.
N3                Have frequent mood swings.
N4                          Often feel blue.
N5                             Panic easily.
O1                         Am full of ideas.
O2         Avoid difficult reading material.
O3 Carry the conversation to a higher level.
O4          Spend time reflecting on things.
O5     Will not probe deeply into a subject.

Factor Analysis

Determining Number of Factors 

# Parallel analysis to determine optimal number of factors
pa_result <- fa.parallel(
  bfi,
  fa = "fa",
  n.iter = 100,
  use = "pairwise.complete.obs",
  main = "Parallel Analysis: BFI Data"
)
Parallel analysis suggests that the number of factors =  6  and the number of components =  NA

Exploratory Factor Analysis Using 6 Factors

Perform FA with 6 factors identified by the parallel analysis

fa_result <- fa(
  bfi,
  nfactors = pa_result$nfact,
  rotate = "oblimin",
  fm = "ml"
)
Loading required namespace: GPArotation
# Extract loading matrix for interpretation
loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |> as.data.frame()
round(loadings_matrix, 2)
# Extract factor correlation matrix
factor_cor_mat <- fa_result$Phi |> as.data.frame()
round(factor_cor_mat, 2)

Interpreting Factor Analysis Results

Create variable information dataframe from BFI dictionary

variable_info <- data.frame(
  variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary),
  description = bfi.dictionary$Item,
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

head(variable_info, 10)

Set up persistent chat session

chat <- chat_fa(
  provider = "ollama",
  model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",
  # set temperature and seed for reproducibility
  params = params(temperature = 0, seed = 42)
)

print(chat)
Factor Analysis Chat Session
Provider: "ollama"
Model: "gpt-oss:20b-cloud"
Created: 2025-11-02 03:03:07.081736
Interpretations run: 0

We now generate factor interpretations using the specified LLM:

result <- interpret_fa(
    loadings = loadings_matrix,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  n_emergency = 2,
  additional_info = NULL,
  factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat,
  sort_loadings = TRUE,
  suppress_small = TRUE,
  word_limit = 100,
  max_line_length = 80,
  silent = FALSE,
  echo = "none",
  output_format = "markdown",
  heading_level = 2,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  chat_session = chat
)
ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character
ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud"

  • Factor 3 (7.7%): Conscientiousness
  • Factor 4 (6.8%): Agreeableness
  • Factor 5 (6.3%): Openness
  • Factor 6 (3.1%): Low Openness/Conscientiousness

    ML4 = .02, ML6 = .18

    ML4 = .25, ML6 = .14
  • ML4: ML2 = .02, ML1 = -0.19, ML3 = .19,
    ML5 = .25, ML6 = .02
  • ML6: ML2 = .18, ML1 = -0.06, ML3 = -0.03,
    ML5 = .14, ML4 = .02

Detailed Factor Interpretations

Factor 1 (ML2):: Negative Affect

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 9.22% nFactor Correlations: ML1 = .25, ML3 = -0.18, ML5 = -0.10, nnML4 = .02, ML6 = .18

nnVariables:nn 1. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .851) 2. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .851) 3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .639) 4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .402) 5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Weak, .389)

LLM Interpretation:
ML2 captures the core of Neuroticism, with strong loadings on anger, irritability, mood swings, sadness, and panic. The factor shows convergent validity: all five negative affect items load above .39, indicating a coherent construct of emotional instability. Discriminant validity is supported by low correlations with other factors (e.g., .02 with ML4). The factor explains 9.2% of variance, making it the most substantial dimension. Its positive loadings on N4 and N5 reinforce the emotional distress component, while the near-zero loadings on other traits confirm distinctness.

Factor 2 (ML1):: Low Extraversion

Number of significant loadings: 7 nVariance explained: 7.9% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .25, ML3 = -0.22, ML5 = -0.31, nnML4 = -0.19, ML6 = -0.06

nnVariables:nn 1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .686) 2. E1, Don’t talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .587) 3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -0.550) 4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .436) 5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Moderate, -0.405) 6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .355) 7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -0.349)

LLM Interpretation:
ML1 represents Introversion, evidenced by high positive loadings on E1 (talk less) and E2 (social avoidance) and negative loadings on E3–E5 (captivation, friendliness, leadership). The factor also captures mild negative affect through N4 and N5, and a modest openness element via O4. Convergent validity is clear: all five Extraversion items load strongly, albeit with opposite signs, forming a coherent low‑extraversion construct. Discriminant validity is upheld by low correlations with ML2 (0.25) and ML3 (–0.22). The factor accounts for 7.9% of variance, highlighting its role as a distinct personality dimension.

Factor 3 (ML3):: Conscientiousness

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 7.71% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -0.18, ML1 = -0.22, ML5 = .19, nnML4 = .19, ML6 = -0.03

nnVariables:nn 1. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .680) 2. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -0.634) 3. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .551) 4. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .547) 5. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -0.541)

LLM Interpretation:
ML3 captures Conscientiousness, with strong positive loadings on C1 (exacting), C2 (perfectionism), and C3 (planned behavior), and strong negative loadings on C4 (half‑way) and C5 (time waste). The pattern demonstrates convergent validity: all five Conscientiousness items load above .54, forming a coherent construct of self‑discipline versus impulsivity. Discriminant validity is evident through modest correlations with other factors (e.g., –0.18 with ML2, 0.19 with ML5). Explaining 7.7% of variance, ML3 represents a distinct, behavior‑oriented personality dimension. Its loadings also align with the broader trait of orderliness, reinforcing its distinctiveness.

Factor 4 (ML5):: Agreeableness

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 6.79% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -0.10, ML1 = -0.31, ML3 = .19, nnML4 = .25, ML6 = .14

nnVariables:nn 1. A2, Inquire about others’ well-being. (Positive, Strong, .688) 2. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .617) 3. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Strong, -0.560) 4. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Moderate, .451) 5. A4, Love children. (Positive, Weak, .391)

LLM Interpretation:
ML5 reflects Agreeableness, with high positive loadings on A2 (inquire well‑being), A3 (comfort others), A4 (love children), and A5 (make people feel at ease), and a strong negative loading on A1 (indifferent to others). The convergent validity is clear: all five Agreeableness items load above .39, forming a coherent empathy‑oriented construct. Discriminant validity is supported by low correlations with ML2 (–0.10) and ML1 (–0.31). Explaining 6.8% of variance, ML5 captures the interpersonal warmth dimension distinct from other personality facets. Its strong negative loading on A1 further distinguishes it from the indifference factor.

Factor 5 (ML4):: Openness

Number of significant loadings: 6 nVariance explained: 6.27% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .02, ML1 = -0.19, ML3 = .19, nnML5 = .25, ML6 = .02

nnVariables:nn 1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .656) 2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .564) 3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Moderate, -0.451) 4. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .392) 5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .376) 6. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Weak, -0.367)

LLM Interpretation:
ML4 represents Openness, with high positive loadings on O1 (full of ideas), O3 (higher‑level conversation), and O4 (reflective thinking), and strong negative loadings on O2 (avoid difficult reading) and O5 (avoid probing). The convergent validity is evident: all five Openness items load above .45, forming a coherent curiosity‑driven construct. Discriminant validity is upheld by low correlations with ML2 (0.02) and ML1 (–0.19). Explaining 6.3% of variance, ML4 captures the imaginative, exploratory facet of personality, distinct from other dimensions. Its negative loadings on O2 and O5 highlight a preference for accessible material over deep analysis.

Factor 6 (ML6):: Low Openness/Conscientiousness

Number of significant loadings: 2 nVariance explained: 3.12% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .18, ML1 = -0.06, ML3 = -0.03, nnML5 = .14, ML4 = .02

nnVariables:nn 1. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Positive, Moderate, .403) 2. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Positive, Weak, .353)

LLM Interpretation:
ML6 captures a low‑openness, low‑conscientiousness, and low‑extraversion profile, evidenced by positive loadings on O5 (avoid probing), O2 (avoid difficult reading), C4 (half‑way), and E4 (make friends easily), and moderate loadings on A5 (make people feel at ease) and N5 (panic). The convergent validity is modest, with several items loading around .30–.40, indicating a secondary dimension of behavioral restraint and emotional reactivity. Discriminant validity is supported by weak correlations with other factors (e.g., .14 with ML5, .18 with ML2). Explaining 3.1% of variance, ML6 represents a distinct, restrained personality facet.

Cross-Loading Variables

Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3):

  • E3: Know how to captivate people.: ML1 (-0.349), ML4 (.392)
  • N4: Often feel blue.: ML2 (.389), ML1 (.436)
  • O2: Avoid difficult reading material.: ML4 (-0.367), ML6 (.353)
  • O4: Spend time reflecting on things.: ML1 (.355), ML4 (.376)
  • O5: Will not probe deeply into a subject.: ML4 (-0.451), ML6 (.403)

Factor Analysis and Interpretation Using 5 Factors

Let’s repeat the interpretation with the theoretical number of 5 factors

fa_result_5f <- fa(
  bfi,
  nfactors = 5,
  rotate = "oblimin",
  fm = "ml",
  scores = TRUE
)

result <- interpret_fa(
    loadings = fa_result_5f$loadings,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  n_emergency = 2,
  additional_info = NULL,
  factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat,
  sort_loadings = TRUE,
  suppress_small = TRUE,
  word_limit = 100,
  max_line_length = 80,
  silent = FALSE,
  echo = "none",
  output_format = "markdown",
  heading_level = 2,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  chat_session = chat
)

Detailed Factor Interpretations

Factor 1 (ML2):: Negative Affect

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 9.65% nFactor Correlations: ML1 = .25, ML3 = -0.18, ML5 = -0.10, nnML4 = .02, ML6 = .18

nnVariables:nn 1. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .852) 2. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .817) 3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .665) 4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .439) 5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .413)

LLM Interpretation:
ML2 captures the core of Neuroticism, with strong loadings on anger, irritability, mood swings, sadness, and panic. The factor shows convergent validity: all five negative affect items load above .39, indicating a coherent construct of emotional instability. Discriminant validity is supported by low correlations with other factors (e.g., .02 with ML4). The factor explains 9.6% of variance, making it the most substantial dimension. Its positive loadings on N4 and N5 reinforce the emotional distress component, while the near‑zero loadings on other traits confirm distinctness.

Factor 2 (ML5):: Agreeableness

Number of significant loadings: 7 nVariance explained: 7.69% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -0.10, ML1 = -0.31, ML3 = .19, nnML4 = .25, ML6 = .14

nnVariables:nn 1. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .668) 2. A2, Inquire about others’ well-being. (Positive, Strong, .603) 3. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Strong, .577) 4. A4, Love children. (Positive, Moderate, .456) 5. E4, Make friends easily. (Positive, Weak, .362) 6. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Weak, -0.360) 7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .303)

LLM Interpretation:
ML5 reflects Agreeableness, with high positive loadings on A2, A3, A4, and A5, and a strong negative loading on A1. The convergent validity is clear: all five agreeableness items load above .39, forming a coherent empathy‑oriented construct. Discriminant validity is upheld by low correlations with ML2 (–0.10) and ML1 (–0.31). Explaining 7.7% of variance, ML5 captures the interpersonal warmth dimension distinct from other personality facets. Its negative loading on A1 further distinguishes it from the indifference factor, reinforcing the construct’s distinctiveness.

Factor 3 (ML1):: Introversion

Number of significant loadings: 7 nVariance explained: 7.36% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .25, ML3 = -0.22, ML5 = -0.31, nnML4 = -0.19, ML6 = -0.06

nnVariables:nn 1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .667) 2. E1, Don’t talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .565) 3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -0.527) 4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .420) 5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Weak, -0.394) 6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .357) 7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -0.341)

LLM Interpretation:
ML1 represents Introversion, evidenced by strong positive loadings on E1 and E2 and negative loadings on E3, E4, and E5. The factor also captures mild negative affect through N4 and N5, and a modest openness element via O4. Convergent validity is clear: all five extraversion items load strongly, albeit with opposite signs, forming a coherent low‑extraversion construct. Discriminant validity is upheld by low correlations with ML2 (0.25) and ML3 (–0.22). Explaining 7.4% of variance, ML1 highlights a distinct introverted personality dimension.

Factor 4 (ML3):: Conscientiousness

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 7.71% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -0.18, ML1 = -0.22, ML5 = .19, nnML4 = .19, ML6 = -0.03

nnVariables:nn 1. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -0.643) 2. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .638) 3. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -0.570) 4. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .564) 5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .532)

LLM Interpretation:
ML3 captures Conscientiousness, with strong positive loadings on C1, C2, and C3 and strong negative loadings on C4 and C5. The pattern demonstrates convergent validity: all five conscientiousness items load above .54, forming a coherent construct of self‑discipline versus impulsivity. Discriminant validity is evident through modest correlations with other factors (e.g., –0.18 with ML2, 0.19 with ML5). Explaining 7.7% of variance, ML3 represents a distinct, behavior‑oriented personality dimension. Its loadings also align with the broader trait of orderliness, reinforcing its distinctiveness.

Factor 5 (ML4):: Openness

Number of significant loadings: 6 nVariance explained: 6.25% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .02, ML1 = -0.19, ML3 = .19, nnML5 = .25, ML6 = .02

nnVariables:nn 1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .633) 2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .534) 3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Strong, -0.522) 4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Moderate, -0.441) 5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .379) 6. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .315)

LLM Interpretation:
ML4 represents Openness, with high positive loadings on O1, O3, and O4 and strong negative loadings on O2 and O5. The convergent validity is evident: all five openness items load above .45, forming a coherent curiosity‑driven construct. Discriminant validity is upheld by low correlations with ML2 (0.02) and ML1 (–0.19). Explaining 6.3% of variance, ML4 captures the imaginative, exploratory facet of personality, distinct from other dimensions. Its negative loadings on O2 and O5 highlight a preference for accessible material over deep analysis, reinforcing the construct’s uniqueness.

print(chat)

Export Functionality

We can export the results to multiple formats

# TXT export
export_interpretation(result,
                      format = "txt",
                      file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis"))
pander::pander(sessionInfo())

R version 4.5.1 (2025-06-13 ucrt)

Platform: x86_64-w64-mingw32/x64
